The gain and pain in taking the pilot seat: learning dynamics in a non immersive virtual solar system
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 26 September 2006

The gain and pain in taking the pilot seat: learning dynamics in a non immersive virtual solar system

  • Elhanan Gazit1,
  • Yoav Yair2 &
  • David Chen3 

Virtual Reality volume 10, pages271–282(2006)Cite this article

  • 196 Accesses

  • 6 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This study describes and analyzes the learning interactions of nine high-school students’ free exploration of a virtual solar system (VSS). The VSS is a non-immersive three dimensional virtual environment based on real NASA planetary images. The computer screen serves as a “spacecraft’s window” for the learner to “fly” between objects, to change the system’s frame of reference and its pace. A systematic analysis of participants’ real-time observable interactions together with what they said revealed that each of them created an unique learning pattern within at least five different dimensions: (1) the cognitive dimension, (2) the affective dimension, (3) the navigation dimension, (4) the interface dimension, and (5) the assistance seeking dimension. The construction of meaning emerged as a non-linear process, which includes transitions between and within these dimensions. Three different styles of learning interactions were identified, suggesting that individual differences might be enhanced due to the unique VSS’ features. Overall, the VSS served as an enriching and motivational learning experience. The design of additional navigation tools and content scaffolding might help participants’ in building a sustained deep scientific understanding.

Theoretical background

Over the last ten years many educational virtual reality environments (VEs), representing abstract scientific phenomena, have been developed to support scientific learning (Dede et al. 2000; Erickson 1993; Keating et al. 2002). Winn (1993) suggests that VEs afford a new type of direct learning, which enhances the learners’ motivation and their knowledge acquisition. Virtual reality (VR) is defined in Encyclopedia Britannica as

The use of computer modeling and simulation to enable a person to interact with an artificial three-dimensional visual or other sensory environment. VR applications immerse the user in a computer-generated environment that simulates reality through the use of interactive devices, which send and receive information

(VR, Britannica 2005).

The simplest form of virtual reality is a three dimensional image that can be explored interactively at a personal computer, usually by manipulating keys or the mouse. These kinds of VR environments are called “non-immersive” VR environments. “Immersive VR environments” include head mounted display (HMD), gloves and other hepatic accessories or CAVE displays which constitute a full “immersive” experience for the user. Steuer (1995) noted that many definitions of VR refer to specific technologies without taking into account the user. Therefore, he defined “Virtual Reality” as:

A real or simulated environment in which a perceiver experiences telepresence (Steuer 1995, p 34).

The term “telepresence” include both teleportation and the experience of “presence” the generic perception of “being” in an artificial or remote environment in virtual environments.

Furness et al. (1997) put a special focus on the general potential benefits of using VEs for teaching and learning complex scientific concepts, stating that:

VR improves learning, when it does, by providing the learners with new, direct experiences of phenomena they could not have experienced before, either in direct interaction with the real world or using other technologies. (Furness et al. 1997, p. 7).

Additionally, Furness et al. (1997) suggested that VEs are engaging and seductive, and can support the teaching of complex topics with less need to simplify them. In a VE learners can easily and without effort visit places and view objects from different points of view, and can manipulate variables that cannot be manipulated in the real world. This emphasizes the notion that VEs are ideal for learning complex systems (DiSessa 1986). For example, Dede et al. (2000) found that students observing a virtual electrical field via HMD from a global and local frame of reference understood the scientific concepts better than those viewing the phenomenon from a single local frame of reference. Additionally, subjects who experienced a three-dimensional simulation gained a better conception of the three-dimensional structure of an electrical field compared to those who used a two-dimensional simulation. However, Antonietti (2000) and Youngbult (1998) argue that the research on the educational potential of virtual environments is in its early stages, with studies focusing mainly on outcomes rather than on real-time learning processes. Likewise, Kennedy (2004) emphasized the need to assess both functional and cognitive interactivity in multimedia learning environments.

Recent developments in the design and use of VR environments in education are focusing on creating an appealing user experiences based on the successes of videogames design. A well documented research project is the multi-user virtual environment experiential (MUVEE) Simulator (Dede and Ketelhut 2003).

In a play like scenarios students explore and collaborate to solve ecological problems in a 19th century VE city called River City. Recently, Dede et al. (2005) reported that using the MUVEE increased students’ motivation and engagement in the learning activities, improved students’ attendance and decreased students’ disruptive behavior. Another study used a three dimensional XII Century Portuguese Romanesque castle, for studying history by pre-service history teachers (Gonçalves 2005). The immersive VE reconstruction was done by using a low-cost video game Quake engine. Preliminary results show that after exploring the Virtual castle via HMD the pre-service teachers identified some of its educational advantages but still described difficulties in actually implementing the VR technology in their classes. Moreover, the result suggests a direct relationship between a traditional pedagogical approach and a bigger reluctance to use the VE. Likewise, Shin et al. (2005) found that undergraduates in a pre-service science teacher program hold positive attitudes with respect of to the use of full immersive virtual reality environments in their classroom and the were more interested in the VR system than any other teaching materials.

Although the studies described above serve as promising indicators for the future of VR in education, the authors of this study argue that there is a need in basic empirical studies which focus on the learners’ interactions within immersive and non-immersive VEs. Only few studies systematically look into the real-time learning processes, which take while students interact in VEs. Form this perspective, VEs can be see as research labs which afford systematic studies on people actions and learning. Rienks et al. (2005) implemented this approach by using an immersive VR environment for studying human meeting interactions behaviors.

The virtual solar system (VSS)

The solar system is a complex scientific concept. Its dynamic nature, vast spatial dimensions and different time scale cannot be perceived directly by the senses. In order to understand the basic astronomical phenomena such as the day-night cycle, seasonal changes, moon’s phases, and eclipses, one must visualize the relative motions and positions of the planetary objects in a three dimensional space, as these may appear from different perspectives simultaneously (Parker and Heywood 1998). Nussbaum (1985) argued that the cognitive difficulty of abandoning the geocentric viewpoint is a fundamental factor shaping students’ misconceptions of the basic astronomical phenomena (day–night cycle, moon phases, and the annual seasons). Vosniadou and Brewer (1994), Sharp (1996), Broughton (1998), and Baxter (1989), all found that students often hold intuitive mental models of these phenomena.

The VSS, designed by Yair et al. (2001) is a non-immersive three dimensional simulation, based on real NASA images taken form various spacecraft missions, and is a state-of-the-art scientific visualization of astronomical knowledge. It was developed as a part of a novel learning environment for studying astronomy through a joint effort of the Center for Education Technology (CET) and the Science and Technology Education Center at Tel-Aviv University (SATEC). The VSS is a major component in the “Touch the Sky Touch the Universe” CD-ROM, which was originally developed for the Israeli educational system and is widely used in schools throughout the country. An English version was developed in 2001 and is now available as a commercial product by Brittanica.com (there are also translations in German, French, Spanish, Hungarian and other European languages). Newer versions of the software include a “fly-over-terrain” above the Lunar and Martian surfaces (Yair et al. 2003). The VSS developed by Yair et al. (2001) shows the planetary objects as they revolve in their orbits against the constant background of the Milky Way and the stars. The solar system was scaled-down while the Keplerian motion was kept at the correct relative rates. High-resolution NASA images were used to construct the objects, and their numerical data was kept with great accuracy. The computer mouse interface is used to change one’s viewpoint while “flying” in a three dimensional space. The orientation difficulties and “vertigo” feeling which may accompany learning in a virtual-environment is minimized by the display of a traditional, two-dimensional dynamic map of the solar system. A dynamic camera icon that is projected on the map represents the user’s location and observation point with respect to the viewed object and to the entire solar system. This map helps to navigate and orient the user, and facilitates the learning experience. The user has a navigational “remote control” with arrows to steer and change the orientation in three-dimensional space. The VSS enables high levels of interactivity by manipulating the computer mouse, or by using a virtual “navigator” tool. The VSS has a dynamic frame of reference, which can be altered by selecting different objects. Each time an object is selected by a mouse click, it becomes the VSS’s new computerized frame of reference. Unlike the real solar system, the VSS space can be manipulated by the user in numerous ways. There are four computerized observational modes, which the user can choose from: a Free-Mode, a Sun-in-Site Mode ,a Planetary Mode , and a Geocentric Mode (an elaborated description of these four observation modes appears in Yair et al. 2001). Moreover, the user can change the pace of the entire system by accelerating or slowing the rotation and revolution rates.

The VSS is a strong exploratory tool, which enables the investigation of how basic phenomena would change as a result of these modifications. “What if” questions are useful for elucidating complex astronomical phenomena (Comins 1999). The VSS allows a direct study of questions such as “what would happen if the Earth and Moon revolved faster”, where the consequences are apparent immediately on the computer screen. Additionally, the VSS combines symbolic information with iconic representations. The VSS enables a new learning experience, which has not been systematically studied yet.

The research goals and questions

The main goal of the current study was to describe and analyze the learning interactions of high-school students’ while they explore the virtual solar system (VSS) for the first time.

The main research questions were:

  1. 1.

    What are the characteristics of the student’s interactions during the VSS’s free exploration task?

  2. 2.

    What are the characteristics of the student’s learning interactions during the VSS’ free exploration task and how does the scientific conceptual understanding regarding the solar system as a complex system develops in real-time?

Methodology

Since the present study was an exploratory case study, no preliminary hypotheses were formulated. Case study methodology affords a systematic examination of learning processes (Stake 1995). Young (1995) and Marshall (1999) suggested that qualitative and quantitative changes of the learning goals and choices made by the learner in real time could reveal the patterns of the learning processes.

Constructivism emphasizes that new knowledge is a personal creation that is socially mediated (Tobin and Tippins 1993). Over the past 20 years, Professor Kurt Fischer (Fischer 1980; Schwartz and Fischer 2003) has developed his theory of skill which focuses on the ways people develop their skills and the ways they learn in various domains. According to his theory, learning, inspired by new problems, involves movement through a portion of one’s developmental framework. Analysis of this process is the basis of an approach for studying learning called microdevelopment (Granott and Parzille 2002). Granott and Parziale (2002) define “microdevelopment” as a process of change in abilities, knowledge, and understanding occurring in short time spans. The main idea behind the micro development approach is to give scientists a better picture of how learning occurs in real time, rather than relying on snapshots of what children learn at particular points. Psychologists and teachers typically assess children’s learning by giving a pretest to a group of children, putting an educational intervention in place, and then returning several weeks or months later to administer a post-test. By contrast, a microdevelopmental approach involves videotaping children actions as they deal with a specific task, coding the responses or words and gestures as they work, and then systematically analyzing all of the information. The microdevelopment approach was selected to examine the learner’s real-time interactions and to reveal changes and patterns in the subsequent qualitative and quantitative development of the learners’ behavior and thinking.

Data collection

Nine 10th grade students (5 boys, 4 girls) aged between 15 and 16 years, volunteered to participate in the study. Their overall grades were above the average (B and higher).

All nine participants did not study astronomy formally and a pretest questionnaire revealed that that they all held an inaccurate partial knowledge of astronomy. The study was conducted at the university lab in the form of individual session, lasting between 1.5 and 2 h each. Each of the sessions was repeated four times with different tasks. Prior to the first session, each participant was shown a 4-min introductory video, displaying the main features of the VSS. The participant was instructed to freely explore the VSS, for as long as she/he liked. The session was followed by an interview. Participants’ real-time actions together with what they said were captured directly from the computer screen by connecting a low cost Aver-key 300 PC-to-TV convector device of AverMedia Inc. and the computer digital dash microphone to a standard VCR.

Data analysis

After extensive, repeated viewing of participants’ observable actions together with what they said, a coding scheme was designed. Each participant’s action was coded within one-tenth of a second resolution by using the Observer (Gazit and Chen 2003). The Observer™ is a software package for the collection, management, analysis, and presentation of observational data (Noldus et al. 2000). One can use it to record activities, postures, movements, positions, facial expressions, social interactions, or any other aspect of human or animal behavior. Finally, the coded files were analyzed by using the Observer™ software. The videotapes were transcribed and an inductive thinking-aloud protocol analysis was performed in which patterns, themes, and categories of analysis were extracted from the data (Patton 1990). It is important to note, that the coding scheme was not set in advance, but rather developed after numerous observations. The researcher and a research assistant coded a 2-h video for reliability testing. The reliability was found to be 95% for the first level of analysis, and 85.5% for the think-aloud protocol analysis.

Results

The results section is divided into three sub-sections. The first section reports on the participants’ learning interactions process and the three learning interactions styles. The second sub-section reports on the affective–cognitive interplay found within the learning interactions process. The third sub-section reports on participant support seeking dimension dynamics—the different types of help requests made by the participants while they perform the task.

The coding scheme consisted of two different levels: the first level referred to participants’ basic interaction behaviors, and the second level referred to participants’ think-aloud protocol analysis. The first coding level yielded a database of 2,575 actions. Table 1 shows the basic interaction behaviors in the VSS (see Table 1).

Transcription of the think-aloud protocols of the nine participants yielded 1,423 items.

This formed the second coding level data bank. Following an extensive protocol analysis, each verbal sentence was classified as one of five dimensions: the interface dimension, the navigation dimension, the cognitive dimension, the affective dimension, and the support-seeking dimension. Table 2 shows the five-dimensions coding scheme used to map participants’ free exploration task think-aloud protocol (See Table 2).

The results show that the learning process within the VSS is a multi-dimensional process composed of at least five dimensions: the interface dimension, the navigation dimension, the cognitive dimension, the affective dimension, and the support seeking dimension. The cognitive dimension was composed from two sub-categories, which represent different frames of reference: a local frame of reference and the global frame of reference. In the cognitive- local dimension, each participant focused on the system’s planetary objects from a local frame of reference. At the local-declarative level, the participant focused on the objects’ visual and symbolic features. For example, AR (boy, age 16 years, 5 months) said:

I see that planet MARS’s color is red, and it has a white ice cap on its’ poles.

Six participants moved to a local-conceptual level by comparing and linking the object’s features. For example, after AR (boy, age 16 years, 5 months) shifted his frame of reference from Mars to Earth, he said:

It’s very interesting, I see that on Mars the day and night are almost the same as on Earth and it has two ice poles, a north pole and a south pole, like ours. (Fig. 1)

In the cognitive-global dimension, each participant focused on the solar system from a global frame of reference. In the global-declarative level, the participant identifies and collects visual features and symbolic facts of the entire solar system or a sub-system (a planet and its moons). For example, OR (girl, age 15 years, 1 month) said

I see that all nine planets revolve in the same direction.

AN (girl, age 15 years 2 months) said

It’s so beautiful! I see that Saturn has six moons.

Four participants moved to a global-conceptual level by making categorizations and generalizations about the system as a whole. For example, AN (girl, age 15 years, 2 months) observed:

I can see that as we move away from the Sun, the relative distance between the Planets and the Sun is getting larger (Fig. 2).

The findings show that four participants frequently shifted their frame of reference between the cognitive-local dimension and the cognitive-global dimension at the declarative level. Within the navigational dimension, each participant learned to navigate in a three-dimensional space, to scan and search for unseen objects or else got “lost” in space. In the interface dimension, each participant developed his or her interface usability skills. Within the affective dimension, both joy and frustration occurred and these were interwoven with the cognitive dimension expressions (as appear in the examples above).

Within the support-seeking dimension, participants usually asked for technical support at the beginning of the session, which was followed by questions regarding the VSS features in the course of the session (this was mainly due to the absence of the user’s manual throughout the sessions).

The frequency percentage of the participants’ multi-dimensional verbal expressions throughout the free exploration task is presented in Fig. 3.

Figure 3 shows the multi-dimensional nature of the learning interactions process, with participants creating their own unique learning path within the four main dimensions It shows the multi-dimensional frequency percentages of participants’ free exploration think-aloud protocol analysis (n = 1,236). The support seeking dimension (n = 187) was analyzed separately (See Sect. 4.2). Three different types of learning interactions styles can be seen in Fig. 3: a superficial learning interaction style, an object-oriented style, and a flexible object-system style. In a superficial learning interaction style, learners focused mainly on gaining control over the interface and to navigate in the three-dimensional space. Three participants, EY (age 15 years, 8 months), AL (age 16 years, 4 months) and SV (age 15 years, 5 months) (the 4th, 5th, and 6th columns respectively, from the left) displayed this pattern, and references to the interface and the navigation dimensions exceeded 60% of the total number of verbal phrases. This superficial learning interaction style was reflected in their rapid exploration pace, their frequent movement between the planetary objects, and their frequent manipulation of the observational modes and points of view. In an object-oriented learning interaction style, learners focused on the system’s parts one at a time, collecting separate facts and noticing their visual attributes (declarative level), while paying little attention to the system’s overall visual attributes (less than 15% of all verbal expressions). AR (boy, age 16 years, 5 months) and DO (boy, age 16 years, 6 months) demonstrated this learning pattern (the 1st and 9th columns respectively, from the left). The accompanying interaction behavior patterns consisted of flying around the planetary objects. By contrast, a flexible object-system exploration style involved the tendency to observe the system from a global frame of reference as well. MI (age 16 years, 2 months), OR (girl, age 15 years, 1 month), and AN (girl, age 15 years, 2 months) (the 3rd, the 7th and the 9th columns from the left, respectively) demonstrated this style which resulted in the formation of a cognitive-local and cognitive-global “net” of facts (declarative level), which in turn afforded the emergence of conceptual knowledge for both the objects as parts and the system as a whole.

These findings demonstrate the overall individual differences in the learning interactions. However, they represent only a static, and thus limited, “snap-shot” of the learning process. In order to reveal the dynamics of the learning interactions, which evolved over time, an analysis based on the Observer™ software’s “Time-event plot” function was performed. Since each verbal expression was recorded as an event, it was easy to perform a sequentially ordered think-aloud protocol analysis. The analysis served to describe the learning process within the VSS, as it unfolded throughout the sessions. It revealed two major patterns in the microdevelopment of participants’ scientific understanding: (1) the non-linear process construction of meaning included transitions between and within dimensions, (2) the development of a scientific understanding of the solar system as a complex system emerged in a fluctuating pattern (Fig. 4).

Figure 4 shows three participants’ real-time microdevelopment trajectories when performing the VSS free exploration task. Each point within the graph represents a verbal phrase. The X-axis represents the phrase’s ordinal number along the timeline. The upper graph shows DO’s object-oriented learning interaction pattern.

DO (boy, age 16 years, 5 months) focused mainly on the cognitive-local dimension, and shifted between a single planetary object and the navigational dimension. The middle graph demonstrates MI’s (girl, age 16 years, 2 months) flexible object-system learning interaction pattern. MI frequently shifted her frame of reference, moving between the cognitive-local dimension and the cognitive-global dimension at both the declarative and conceptual levels. The lower trajectory graph shows EY’s superficial learning pattern. EY (boy, age 15 years, 8 months) focused mainly on the desire “to know what it feels like to fly between the planets”, paying little attention to viewing the solar system from a global frame of reference. Much of his efforts were devoted to navigating between the planetary objects, to search and scan for new objects, such as the asteroids, and to understand the differences between the computerized observational modes and the real-world point of view. EY’s microdevelopment learning interaction trajectory demonstrates that taking an active “pilot seat” role is very demanding with respect to navigating and orientating in a three dimensional space. This finding was found among all nine participants. In addition, all participants expressed their feelings of joy or frustration during the exploration process.

Focusing on the affective-cognitive interplay

A systematical examination revealed two types of cognitive-affective interplay: the “enhancement” effect involved the joy of discovering new facts accompanied by some frustration resulting from inadequate navigation skills in the VSS. Other “affective promoters” were identified as “aesthetic joy” and “existential feelings”. For example, while observing the solar system from a global frame of reference, AN (girl, age 15 years, 2 months) expressed her existential feeling by stating that “The more we explore space, the more we see how small we are, that we are not so important in this vast universe. Suddenly our problems seem less important in proportion to the other very important things that occur in the universe”. The opposite “disengage” negative effect consisted of long durations of frustration that resulted mainly from navigational and interface usability problems. An examination of the frequencies distribution of the seven main affective categories (n = 67) across participants’ relative timeline was preformed (See Fig. 5).

Figure 5 shows that the enjoying the beauty of the scientific phenomena was the most frequent during the first two quarters of the session. During the third and the fourth quarter of the sessions the overall frequencies of all sentences were reduced, but remained relatively high compared to sentences relating to the other affective categories. The distributed frequencies over time of other “positive affective expressions” such as the joy of discovery, expressing the motivation to explore the VSS, or being immersed within the VSS were less frequent. The frequencies of the “disengage affective expressions” such as boredom or frustration were relatively low throughout the session. This indicates the participants’ overall positive learning experience. Combining the positive affective categories along the timeline demonstrates the important impact of the affective dimension to the learning experience. In addition, Fig. 5 shows that the participants’ frustration expressions were found to accompany navigation and orientation difficulties. The uniqueness of the VSS’s non-intuitive dynamic frames of reference might contribute to these difficulties. These difficulties were reflected in the participants’ follow-up interviews. For example, EY (boy, age 15 years, 8 months) commented:

“I have experienced navigational problems in a free observational mode. In this three dimensional space you have got all sorts of movements, unlike in our real two and a half dimensional environments, so a fish which usually moves up and down and spins around would have a much better control of the VSS environment than me” [smiles].

Nevertheless, all nine participants claimed that taking an active role as “pilots” instead of being passive observers was the highly motivating factor for learning. All nine participants also reported a sense of being “immersed” within the VSS. For example, SV ( a girl, age 15 years, 5 months) noted:

You feel that you are flying between the planets. It enabled me to see things I did not see before, to imagine things I could not imagine before. Here I am the driver, not just a passenger in the back seat of the car.

Focusing on the support-seeking dimension dynamics

During the sessions, the participants felt free to ask for support. The frequencies distribution of the four main support-seeking categories (n = 187) is plotted on the quarterly timeline (Fig. 6).

Figure 6 demonstrates that, as expected, there has been a decline over time in requests for technical support (the dotted line). The frequency of questions relating to the VSS’s representations remained relatively high in the second and the third quarters of the session. Typical questions expressed by the participants were:

why are the asteroids’ orbits colored red and the other objects’’ orbits colored blue?

Are the planets’ relative positions in the VSS exactly the same position as in the real world?

Requests for instant feedback such as “Am I right about this?” were most frequent initially but overall, the trend was similar to the decline in frequencies of the technical support category. Additionally, requests for astronomical information remained stable during the first three quarters followed by a slight decline in the fourth quarter. A closer look at the support seeking dimension dynamics affords a new and different perspective on the learning interactions in the VSS. The analysis showed that taking the “pilot seat” is a complex task in which gaining total control over the learning interaction process is accompanied by a high frequency of requests for support seeking and support. Table 3 summarizes the gain and pain in taking the pilot seat, based on our findings concerning the learning interactions and outcomes.

Discussion

Overall, it is clear that exploring the VSS served as an enriching learning experience. Three main conclusions could be drawn form our study: First, the results show that constructing meaning by interacting within a virtual reality environment is a highly complex process. Empirical studies of this complexity would meet the challenge stated by Antonietti (2000) and Youngbult (1998), regarding the development of a coherent theory for learning in virtual reality environments and its educational potential. Second, the three different exploration patterns described in our study, demonstrate that providing a flexible, open, constructivist-learning opportunity does not necessarily result in a high level of conceptual understanding. The VSS’s unique features might have increased individual differences in the learning interactions, as learners created their own path within the dynamic learning environment according to their personal internal tendencies. Moreover, the learning within virtual environments included a complex interplay between the affective dimension and the cognitive dimension. One pedagogical implication could be that teachers should encourage the participants’ “affective promoters”, while also paying attention to possible “affective pitfalls”. Hence, enhanced introduction tutorials which focus on the unique VSS features, a well-planned interaction with a teacher or a built in smart agent could assist the learners in taking the “pilot” role in the exploration journey. Recently, Yair et al. (2003) suggested a structured mediation process based on a “Thinking Journey” methodology, by which teachers can guide their students to use the VSS to explore the Moon and the planet Mars. Additionally, the design of future dynamic digital learning environments should address individual differences by providing appropriate flexibility and an intelligent built-in feedback feature, which affords real-time peer interactions. An example of incorporating innovative A.I technology, which generates semi-automated movie summaries, was recently presented (Friedman et al. 2004). Moreover, the design of large-scale virtual environments should be accompanied with intuitive navigation tools to enable effective orientation and navigation. An example of such technique was suggested by Pierce and Pausch (2004), in which users are able to actively employ visible landmarks. Actual and symbolic place representations allow users to efficiently detect and travel to distant locations. Implementing these techniques might support “undistorted” conceptualization of the phenomena under study. All of the above could assist students in building a more sustained and deep scientific understanding of the subject matter at hand. To conclude, we hope that our learning interactions multi-dimensional analysis could serve other related research areas which study interactions in virtual environments that represent complex scientific and professional domains, such as multi-user combat simulations training, business game simulation training, virtual rehabilitation environments, interactive TV environments, and video-games based learning, to name a few.
